StudyInfo.StudyNameEntrez: Rapid Whole Genome Sequencing for Genetic Disease Diagnosis in Neonatal Intensive Care Units

Person.Organization: RADY PEDIATRIC GENOMICS & SYSTEMS MEDICINE INSTITUTECHILDREN'S MERCY HOSP (KANSAS CITY, MO)RADY CHILDREN'S HOSPITAL - SAN DIEGO

Policy.acknowledgement_statement: The dataset used for the analyses described in this manuscript were obtained from the database of Genotype and Phenotype (dbGaP) found at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/gap. Samples and associated genotype and phenotype data for the studies "Rapid Whole Genome Sequencing for Genetic Disease Diagnosis in Neonatal Intensive Care Units" and "Effectiveness of acuity – guided exome and genome sequencing for etiologic diagnosis of neurodevelopmental disorders" were provided by Stephen F. Kingsmore, M.B., Ch.B., D.Sc., whose project was supported by the Marion Merrell Dow Foundation, Children’s Mercy - Kansas City, Patton Trust, W.T. Kemper Foundation, Pat & Gil Clements Foundation, Claire Giannini Foundation, Black & Veatch, NICHD and NHGRI (U19HD077693), and NCATS (CTSA TL1TR000120), and in-kind support from Illumina, Inc. Dr. Kingsmore and his collaborator, Neil Miller, also acknowledge the helpful comments of R. Cohen and V. Corbin as well as the technical assistance of A Keithly and M. Clifton. See C. J. Saunders, et al. Rapid Whole-Genome Sequencing for Genetic Disease Diagnosis in Neonatal Intensive Care Units. Sci. Transl. Med. 4, 154ra135 (2012), and S. E. Soden, et al. Effectiveness of acuity – guided exome and genome sequencing for etiologic diagnosis of neurodevelopmental disorders. Sci. Transl. Med. (in press) (2014) for details of the original studies.
Policy.ic_specific_access_term:
Full or expedited IRB approval is required to access these data. We do not accept "Research Exempt Status."Additionally, the IRB approval must specifically refer to the use of this dataset [Rapid Whole Genome Sequencing for Genetic Disease Diagnosisin Neonatal Intensive Care Units].
The requestor must also provide a letter of collaboration with Dr. Stephen Kingsmore and his associates.
The progress report should cite work done that relates specifically to this dataset [Rapid Whole Genome Sequencing for Genetic Disease Diagnosis in Neonatal Intensive Care Units] and not just a generic report for a series of datasets that may have been requested at the same time.

GSR_Access.gsr_mode_label: Unrestricted access (institution did not respond within six months)

ConsentGroup.title: General Research Use (IRB, PUB, COL, NPU, MDS, GSO)
ConsentGroup.name: GRU-IRB-PUB-COL-NPU-MDS-GSO
ConsentGroup.Use-Restriction: Use of the data is limited only by the terms of the model Data Use Certification. Requestor must provide documentation of local IRB approval. Requestor agrees to make results of studies using the data available to the larger scientific community. Requestor must provide a letter of collaboration with the primary study investigator(s). Use of the data is limited to not-for-profit organizations. Use of the data includes methods development research (e.g., development of software or algorithms). Use of the data is limited to genetic studies only.

Policy.acknowledgement_statement: The dataset used for the analyses described in this manuscript were obtained from the database of Genotype and Phenotype (dbGaP) found at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/gap. Samples and associated genotype and phenotype data for the Rapid Whole Genome Sequencing for Genetic Disease Diagnosis in Neonatal Intensive Care Units were provided by Stephen Kingsmore, M.D. whose project was supported by the Merrell Dow Foundation, Children's Mercy Hospital, and in-kind support from Illumina, Inc. Dr. Kingsmore and his collaborator, Neil Miller, also acknowledge the helpful comments of R. Cohen and V. Corbin as well as the technical assistance of A Keithly and M. Clifton. See C. J. Saunders, et al. Rapid Whole-Genome Sequencing for Genetic Disease Diagnosis in Neonatal Intensive Care Units. Sci. Transl. Med. 4, 154ra135 (2012), for details of the original study.
Policy.ic_specific_access_term: The progress report should cite work done that relates specifically to this dataset [Rapid Whole Genome Sequencing for Genetic Disease Diagnosis in Neonatal Intensive Care Units] and not just a generic report for a series of datasets that may have been requested at the same time.
